Title: The Diseases of Modern Life: Nineteenth-Century Perspectives

This interdisciplinary project investigates the intersections of stress, overload, and disorders associated with modernity in the nineteenth century, as reflected in literature, science, and medicine. Focusing on Benjamin Ward Richardson's seminal work, Diseases of Modern Life (1876), our research explores the various diseases and disorders that emerged during this period, including those caused by worry and mental strain, lifestyle choices, environmental pollution, financial speculation, and occupational hazards. We will also examine the intersections of health and disease with middle-class culture, education, and travel, as well as the development of phobias and nervous disorders.

Through a holistic and integrative approach, our project aims to track the circulation of ideas across literature, science, and medicine, and to uncover connections between physiological, psychological, and social health or disease. By adopting a cross-disciplinary methodology, we will offer new ways of contextualizing modernity's problems and challenge traditional compartmentalizations of psychiatric, environmental, or literary history.

Our expected outcomes include breaking new ground in scholarship and achieving breakthroughs in understanding the complexities of modernity's diseases. By shedding light on the nineteenth-century roots of contemporary health concerns, our project will provide valuable insights for scholars, policymakers, and the general public. Ultimately, this research will contribute to a deeper understanding of the intricate relationships between human health, societal pressures, and environmental factors, informing strategies for promoting well-being in the modern era.

Title: The Diseases of Modern Life: Nineteenth-Century Perspectives

This project delves into the intersections of stress, overload, and disorders associated with modernity in the 19th century, as reflected in literature, science, and medicine. Using Benjamin Ward Richardson's Diseases of Modern Life (1876) as a framework, we will explore a range of topics, including diseases triggered by worry and mental strain, lifestyle diseases, environmental pollution diseases, and diseases linked to specific professions, finance, and education. We will also examine the imaginative construction of utopias and dystopias in health and disease contexts.

Our objectives are threefold: to track the circulation of ideas across literature, science, and medicine; to explore connections between physiological, psychological, and social health or disease; and to offer new ways of contextualizing modernity's problems. To achieve these goals, we will employ a holistic and integrative Victorian vision, combining cross-disciplinary scholarship to uncover new insights.

We anticipate that this project will break new ground in scholarship, yielding breakthroughs in our understanding of psychiatric, environmental, and literary history. By examining the 19th-century roots of modernity's health challenges, we will gain a deeper understanding of the complex relationships between individual and societal well-being, and shed new light on the ongoing struggles of modern life. Ultimately, this project will provide a nuanced and multifaceted perspective on the diseases of modern life, informing our responses to contemporary health challenges and fostering a more comprehensive understanding of the human experience.
